A. Incorrect: The policy already allows PC3 (source = all).
B. Correct: Expanding the IP pool gives PC3 a public IP.
C. Incorrect: A new policy won’t fix the IP pool issue.
D. Correct: Overload allows multiple PCs to share the same public IP using PAT.

choices.A: In the firewall policy configuration, add 10.0.1.3 as an address object in the source field.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
there is no NAT so the source address still the original, 
There is a VIP so the destination address is translated to the mapped address, 
There is a port forward from 8080 to 80 so the destination port is the mapped port (80)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Just confirmed this is C by testing it in the Training Lab (lab 2 allows you to test this pretty easily).

Selected Answer: C
NAT is disabled on the Allow_access policy, which is the policy of interest here as the traffic is coming IN WAN port1 and going to the server out LAN port3.

B. 10.0.1.254, 10.0.1.10, and 80, respectively

10.200.3.1 --> 10.0.1.254 because NAT enable in firewall policy
10.200.1.10 --> 10.0.1.10 because VIP as Destination
8080 --> 80 because Port Forwarding enabled on VIP

comments.content: the answer is C. the source is 10.200.3.1 since there is no nat enabled on the inbound policy.
NAT is disabled on the Allow_access policy, which is the policy of interest here as the traffic is coming IN WAN port1 and going to the server out LAN port3.

discussion.content: C correct

questions.question_text: Which two attributes are required on a certificate so it can be used as a CA certificate on SSL inspection? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
CA=True
KeyUsage=KeyCertSign

Selected Answer: BD
Pag. 174

Selected Answer: BD
B&D are correct

Selected Answer: BD
page 174 of FGT 7.4 ASG

The CA=True value identifies the certificate as a CA certificate. The KryUsage =KeyCertSign value indicates that the certificate corresponding private key is permitted to sign certificates. see RFC 5280 section 4.2.1.9 basic Constraints.
Answer is B & D
B and D correct

choices.D: The keyUsage extension must be set to keyCertSign
choices.A: The issuer must be a public CA
choices.C: The Authority Key Identifier must be of type SSL
choices.B: The CA extension must be set to TRUE

Selected Answer: ABC
ABC is correct. B and C are understood to be correct, A is correct because flow-based inspection uses hybrid of two scanning options, default and legacy. Default scanning supports scanning of nested archive files without buffering the whole container file whereas legacy mode buffers the whole container file for scanning purposes (of underlying nested files).

questions.question_text: Which three statements explain a flow-based antivirus profile? (Choose three.)

choices.C: FortiGate buffers the whole file but transmits to the client at the same time.
choices.D: If a virus is detected, the last packet is delivered to the client.
choices.E: The IPS engine handles the process as a standalone.
choices.A: Flow-based inspection uses a hybrid of the scanning modes available in proxy-based inspection.
choices.B: Flow-based inspection optimizes performance compared to proxy-based inspection.
